text: [Music]
i'm andy hall
senior solutions architect with aws in
this third video
i'm going to continue where we last left
off and show you how to stand up a full
cicd pipeline using aws code pipeline
aws code build and aws code deploy
to automate the deployment of
application changes in order to start
i'll have to create a new aws code
pipeline by clicking on the create
pipeline button
i'm going to specify a name for my
pipeline in order to make it obvious to
people that this pipeline is used for my
application
i'm going to set the name to ecs aspe
net core
which is the name of the application
additionally
i want to use a new service role that is
correctly configured for my setup
in order to do this i'll make sure that
the
new service role option is selected
along with filling in the name of the
role and ensuring that the
allow aws code pipeline to create a
service role
so that it can be used with this new
pipeline check box
is checked once that's filled in i'm
going to move forward
in the configuration by clicking on the
next button
i want to integrate aws code pipeline
with aws code commit
so that when i check in changes to my
application
the ci cd pipeline will execute in order
to do this
i'm going to select code commit as my
source provider
when i select code commit i can now fill
in
additional details such as the name of
my repository
the branch name that i want to watch for
changes
and how i want the service to detect
changes
to my repository since i have previously
set up
a code commit repository i'm going to
use that one along
with the master branch additionally i'm
going to use the recommended approach
of using amazon cloudwatch events for my
code pipeline to recognize changes in
order to start the ci cd
execution
at this point i can set up my build
stage of the pipeline
since i'm going to use code build i'm
going to select that from the available
build providers
when selecting code build i'll also need
to specify the aws region that i want
this pipeline to run in
i'm going to use the default value which
is my current region
the next thing that i'm going to do is
set up my project within aws code build
in order to do that i'm going to click
on the create
project button
this will display a new page for the
setup of the build project
first i'm going to specify the name for
my build project
to keep things consistent i'm going to
set it to the name of my project
now i can use either a custom ami
or an aws managed image for my build
environment
since i don't need a custom image i'm
going to use an
aws managed instance in order to do this
i'll make sure that the managed image
option is selected
i'll have to specify the target
operating system
for the build environment
since i'm using asp.net core
i can build my application using the
linux operating system instead of a
windows operating system
i'm going to select the operating system
as amazon linux2
additionally i'll set the runtime to
standard
since that has everything that i'll need
and lastly i'm going to use the latest
image
since the goal of my build is to create
a docker image
i'm going to make sure that the build
has elevated privileges
to do this i'm going to click on the
enable this flag if you want to build
docker
images or you want your builds to get
elevated privileges
since i have an existing bpc i want to
make sure that i'm using it for the
build
in order to do that i'm going to specify
the vpc
so that the aws code build project can
access it
now that i've specified my vpc i'm going
to have to specify which
private subnets that aws code build
should access
i'm going to use two private subnets
that are in different availability zones
additionally i'm going to use a security
group that allows access to
all resources within my vpc i've set up
the security group previously so i'm
just going to use this one
in order to ensure that my setup is
correct i'm going to click on the
validate vpc settings button
if i didn't have something set up
correctly this will call out where the
error is
since my vpc setup is correct i'm ready
to specify some details about the
compute instances
that should be used to build my
application since my application is
small
i'm going to use the smallest available
size
in your case you might want to select an
instance that has more available ram
and vcpu
the next thing that i'm going to need to
do is specify the location of my build
spec file
this file is used to list the necessary
steps to build the application
we'll cover the contents of the build
spec file a little bit later
for now let's assume that we're going to
put the build spec
yaml file in the root of the aws code
commit repository
since i might run into issues i'm going
to make sure that the output is dumped

in order to do this i'll just leave the
cloudwatch
logs checkbox checked at this point my
project is set up
so i'm going to click on the continue to

this will save the changes for this

and close this page
since i created the project it has now

i'm going to specify a name and the

now that i have an application known to

i'll need to set up a deployment group

i'll use a name that is similar to the
